RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the jury: jury in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States District Court: United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the jurors: jury in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.undocumented aliens: individuals being smuggled, possibly hidden in a vehicle with fogged windows on a cold night, characterized by unwashed and unkempt appearance, suspected to be in vehicles stopped by Border Patrol agents near the United States-Mexican border, attempting to evade detection, exhibiting efforts to avoid detection by ducking and scrambling, admitted to being undocumented, including three women and five or six men found in a pickup truck camper, perceived as a social problem in controlling hordes from Mexico, unwashed and unkempt, scrambling when approached by Border Patrol agents, moving and slouching low to hide from flashlight beams, reacting to flashlight beams by ducking and scrambling, reacting to a bright light by physical movement in the interior of the pickup truck camper, with an appearance consistent with that of illegal aliens, whose hygienic appearance can vary greatly with subjective perceptions, making efforts to conceal themselves when detected, displaying suspicious behavior such as slouching down or hunkering down when passing Border Patrol agents, carried by a pickup truck camper in numbers up to twenty-two
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck camper: vehicle used for smuggling undocumented aliens on Interstate Highway 35, characterized by heavy loading and difficulty in handling, subject of a suppression motion regarding evidence obtained during its stop and search, with factors such as appearance, behavior of the driver, and number and appearance of passengers considered in determining justification for the stop, stopped more than 100 miles from the United States-Mexican border, often having fogged windows, exhibiting an unusually heavy and overloaded appearance, stopped 115 miles north of the United States-Mexican border, where individuals were scrambling to avoid detection, weaving and lowered rear due to overloading with up to twenty-two people
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant in a court case involving allegations of smuggling undocumented aliens, arguing against the use of the modified Allen charge, seeking post-verdict discovery through juror depositions and interrogatories to determine potential coercion by the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia: court case involving allegations against Maria De Jesus Garcia, with a focus on the modified Allen charge and its potential coercive effect on the jury, currently in deliberation phase with jury requesting information from outside the record and indicating difficulty in reaching a unanimous decision
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pena-Cantu: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pacheco: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Orona-Sanchez: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.TATE: Circuit Judge, dissenting in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexican aliens: individuals suspected of crossing the border illegally, potentially traveling in a crowded pickup truck camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: border crossed by potential illegal aliens, approximately 115 miles south of where the pickup truck camper was stopped
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.marked United States Border Patrol sedan: law enforcement vehicle used for stopping and searching vehicles near the United States-Mexican border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.modified Allen charge: a judicial instruction given to the jury in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia, emphasizing the importance of reaching a verdict, with its potential coercive effect being a point of contention
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.jury in United States v. Maria De Jesus: deliberating body in the court case against Maria De Jesus Garcia, having difficulty reaching a unanimous decision after approximately two hours of deliberation
